citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A male Scarlet Macaw "Big Bird" had complete feather loss on his upper legs and lateral flanks showing bare patches of
skin where the underlying skin appeared normal. The facility representative indicated that the animal's condition was
chronic and due to feather picking by himself and sometimes the other macaw present in the enclosure. The facility
representative also stated that Big Bird's current condition was the worst it has been, but the facility had previously been
in contact with a veterinarian overseeing his care and that he was on a supplement to help with feather loss. No records
on Big Bird documented his feather loss condition, exam or consultation with a veterinarian or a treatment plan. In
discussion with the attending veterinarian, they determined that current care for Big Bird is insufficient and have
scheduled his exam the following week. Failure to use the appropriate methods to control and treat diseases and injuries
in birds may result in prolonging of their illness and contribute to their discomfort. Each exhibitor shall establish and
maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose and
treat diseases and injuries.
Correct by 13 October 2023.

Multiple wire sharp points are found in the outdoor community aviary housing 2 Helmeted Guineafowl, 1 Alexandrine
Parakeet, 1 Scarlet Macaw, 1 Blue-and-Yellow Macaw, 4 Ringneck Doves, and 1 Red-Crested Turaco. The metal wires of
varying gauge are used to secure housing structures or enrichment items and the ends (longest one is approximately 5
inches long) are not tucked and point outward into the enclosure. Primary enclosures housing birds that have sharp points
may cause them injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points or
edges that could injure the birds.
Correct by 13 October 2023.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At time of inspection, there were 3 individually housed birds that cannot see or hear birds of their own or compatible
species including a female Scarlet Macaw "Apache", a female Ringneck Dove "Malibu", and a female Peahen "Gladys".
There were no provisions in the avian environment enhancement plan for the Ringneck Dove and the Peahen to be
provided additional special attention and the provisions listed for the Scarlet Macaw had not been approved by the
Attending Veterinarian. Failure to provide additional environment enhancement for birds in special consideration
categories listed in the regulations may lead to their poor psychological health and welfare. Certain birds must be
provided special attention regarding enhancement of their environment, based on the needs of the individual species
and/or individual bird and in accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian. Birds requiring special attention
include individually housed social species of birds that are unable to see and hear birds of their own or compatible
species.
Correct by 13 October 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A male Scarlet Macaw "Big Bird" had complete feather loss on his upper legs and lateral flanks showing bare patches of 
skin where the underlying skin appeared normal. The facility representative  indicated that the animal's condition was 
chronic and due to feather picking by himself and sometimes the other macaw present in the enclosure. The facility 
representative  also stated that Big Bird's current condition was the worst it has been, but the facility had previously been 
in contact with a veterinarian  overseeing  his care and that he was on a supplement to help with feather loss. No records 
on Big Bird documented his feather loss condition, exam or consultation with a veterinarian  or a treatment plan. In 
discussion with the attending veterinarian,  they determined that current care for Big Bird is insufficient and have 
scheduled his exam the following week. Failure to use the appropriate methods to control and treat diseases and injuries 
in birds may result in prolonging of their illness and contribute to their discomfort. Each exhibitor shall establish and 
maintain programs of adequate veterinary  care that include the appropriate  methods to prevent, control, diagnose and 
treat diseases and injuries.  
 
Correct by 13 October 2023. 
3.153(a)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Multiple wire sharp points are found in the outdoor community aviary housing 2 Helmeted Guineafowl,  1 Alexandrine 
Parakeet, 1 Scarlet Macaw, 1 Blue-and-Yellow  Macaw, 4 Ringneck Doves, and 1 Red-Crested  Turaco. The metal wires of 
varying gauge are used to secure housing structures or enrichment items and the ends (longest one is approximately 5 
inches long) are not tucked and point outward into the enclosure. Primary enclosures housing birds that have sharp points 
may cause them injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points or 
edges that could injure the birds.  
 
Correct by 13 October 2023. 
3.154(c)(4) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.

At time of inspection, there were 3 individually housed birds that cannot see or hear birds of their own or compatible 
species including a female Scarlet Macaw "Apache", a female Ringneck Dove "Malibu", and a female Peahen "Gladys". 
There were no provisions in the avian environment  enhancement plan for the Ringneck Dove and the Peahen to be 
provided  additional special attention and the provisions listed for the Scarlet Macaw had not been approved  by the 
Attending Veterinarian. Failure to provide additional environment  enhancement for birds in special consideration 
categories listed in the regulations may lead to their poor psychological health and welfare. Certain birds must be 
provided  special attention regarding enhancement of their environment,  based on the needs of the individual species 
and/or individual bird and in accordance with the instructions of the attending veterinarian.  Birds requiring special attention 
include individually housed social species of birds that are unable to see and hear birds of their own or compatible 
species.  
 
Correct by 13 October 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
